body:
> However it's strange that failing builds end up in master. I recommend to change the practice and not push or merge into master unless the build is stable (with fast-forward merges and rebasing any pollution of the git history can be avoided)

`master` branch in out case is development branch, not a release one. It has both historical and organizational reasons: we migrated from `svn` where branches and tags are quite expensive, so we haven't adopted gitflow or something similar which use motto `master is stable and always builds` which is relevant for software with CD-pipeline in the first place. Organizational part is even harder, we are group of individuals from different companies and different places around the planet (same applies to all Apache Software Foundation projects). It leads to asynchronous communication with large latencies and more complicated repo guidelines would get a lot of valuable time: both PMC/committers' and contributors'. So other global or organizational tasks have higher prio to me. I think github is not the best place for such discussions, so if you want to continue it and bring to attention of other Tika devs I'll suggest to mail to dev@tika.apache.org (see docs at http://tika.apache.org/mail-lists.html to subscribe).

> which makes it hard to start commiting to the project because one needs a building project in order to start working because suggesting improvements of the base of the latest release produces unnecessary merge work.

Usually it isn't that bad) Also, you can base your patch on release tag, test it and rebase onto `master` before merge. If a build from release tag fails it usually means some exotic environment which slipped off out attention and probably to be fixed in `master` to avoid such issues in next release.

Thanks for you detailed explanation.

> Organizational part is even harder, we are group of individuals from different companies and different places around the planet (same applies to all Apache Software Foundation projects).

That applies to almost any FLOSS project that exists and is hardly worth mentioning. Local distribution and communication latency isn't a good reason to allow failing builds on `master`. The discussion could continue on the mailing list, but I see no sense in it since having a main development branch that doesn't build reliably is a no-go for contributions from my side and it's basically a yes-no-decision - I didn't want to contribute much, but other devs might and it'd be a pity to loose their contributions - it's your decision and I understand you priorities.

> Also, you can base your patch on release tag, test it and rebase onto master before merge.

That causes unnecessary work and should be discouraged. It's a valid workaround for the current situation.

BTW, do you want to have a report for the test failure mentioned above?

> but I see no sense in it since having a main development branch that doesn't build reliably is a no-go for contributions from my side

I completely agree.  Trunk should build...end of story.  This is in fact one of the reasons that I haven't been eager to contribute to some other open source projects.

We found the bug you mentioned during the last release process.  This was a locale bug that was my fault, and which I didn't see on my local machine and which our CI process didn't uncover.  That we didn't catch this earlier is symptomatic of the few number of devs actively building snapshots, so yes, we absolutely need more!

If trunk doesn't build, please do let us know on dev@ or on JIRA.  I share your concern 100% that this is a big problem and will discourage participation if we don't fix it.

@krichter722, I totally agree with you and @tballison that `master` should be stable enough to avoid wasting contributors' time to get it building in their environment. Unfortunately it isn't so yet and should be fixed. My thoughts about making patch against release tag is mere workaround. 

All I said above isn't Tika PMC position but my personal view on what I can do and plan to do in short term future.

> BTW, do you want to have a report for the test failure mentioned above?

Of course, if you would. We appreciate bug reports. I couldn't reproduce it on my laptop with current `master` (4455a6f087bbd52767e55478e9d51fdb39adbce6)

Thanks for this! Unfortunately it breaks the unit tests as it stands, because stream.skip may not skip the whole amount... I've committed a slightly modified version
Thanks for this fast apply of that patch. You should also close the jira ticket.

I've tested the code. To protect us against too large files we crop them.
This now causes the file to unlimeted skip, because it can't skip behind the cropped end of the file.
This is caused by the implementation of skipFully which tries to skip if even there is nothing to skip.
Unlike read, skip will not return -1 if EOF is reached!
Any thoughts on how we should patch skipFully to handle it? Maybe check if skip returns 0, then call a read to see if it's -1?

This looks great!  Would you be able to add a unit test?

Thanks. Yes, I will. I'm also going to add the boundary value.

What d'you think of the names?
I like the names.  I wonder if we should add them as Properties to o.a.t.metadata.Message in tika-core?

Sorry about that, and thank you for figuring out what went wrong.  I completely agree on the superiority of 42.  Does your PR actually fix your problem, though? If you're getting `Picked up...` on stderr...that doesn't equal "".

It doesn't fix my problem, but it makes the cause of the failing test very clear (as opposed to `0 != 42` as output from the failing test).

If not `$_JAVA_OPTIONS` is not defined, the `Picked up ...` messages is not printed to `stderr`, and the test passes.

So, maybe you want to undefine `$_JAVA_OPTIONS` in the test to avoid that the test result is determined by the environment?
Ha, ok.  It is uglier than I'd like to undefine `$_JAVA_OPTIONS` in the child process.  I fixed the test to fail if it finds the parser printing to stderr.

Hi @giuseppetotaro I think this is an excellent addition. I would suggest that although you have grouped the HashMap of Standards Org's by geographical governing entity/country, it may be better to have these listed alphabetically. This is really the only suggestion I would make.

Hi @lewismc, thank you very much for your insightful suggestion. I have updated the `StandardOrganizations` class by using the `TreeMap` instead of the `HashMap` (commit 31625a2ad6b9a4de73aa322845fb1e38ba96177d).
Furthermore, I have added a new regular expression that matches the word "publication" or "standard" within a pattern that is supposed to be a standard (commit 7b869c0c1b132feb691dca645fe9bc689bf320e2). You can find the new workflow [here](https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12885939/flowchart_standards_extraction_v02.png).
Very good @giuseppetotaro , from your workflow I see you have two decision points for determining whether the entity "Matches Standard Organizations"... is the duplicated logic intentional?
Thanks @lewismc. It was my mistake. I have updated the flowchart and now it is correct. Thanks a lot.

For usage questions, please post on the mailing list - https://lists.apache.org/list.html?user@tika.apache.org - or StackOverflow. If you think you've found a bug, please either post on the mailing list, or open a bug in JIRA - https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/TIKA

Hi @chrismattmann, hi @lewismc, I think that it would be useful to have the standard references along with the related scores into the `Metadata` object. To the best of my knowledge, there is no chance to get an "associative array" within a `Metadata` object (i.e., an array of key-value pairs where the key is the reference and the value is the score). Do you think we can extend the `Metadata` class for including also array of objects? Do you have other solutions?
I look forward to have your feedback.

I was getting the same error. Nothing is wrong with your docker setup. The problem was with the download url of **imagenet_lsvrc_2015_synsets.txt** & **imagenet_metadata.txt**. Apparently tf maintainers have moved these meta files and models to another repo https://github.com/tensorflow/serving. 
See, https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tensorflow/models/master/inception/inception/data/imagenet_lsvrc_2015_synsets.txt
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tensorflow/models/master/inception/inception/data/imagenet_metadata.txt
you will get 404. I'll update with the new URLs

The new urls are,
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tensorflow/models/master/research/inception/inception/data/imagenet_lsvrc_2015_synsets.txt
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tensorflow/models/master/research/inception/inception/data/imagenet_metadata.txt
Any thoughts or should this be closed?

Thx. My problem resides in using tika to attempt text extraction from image based pdfs. I installed tesseract and it is being used by tika. I am also using your python wrapper with basic parsing for content. I am not getting anything out of various documents. Sorry if I post in the wrong repository. 
Please advise.

Thank you

hi @r00t1ng got it. So if you are doing text extraction from image based PDFs and using the python wrapper, it should be working. You can control what parsers are getting called by providing a custom tika-config.xml file. Depending on what type of PDF it is, you should check:

    1. Does Tesseract (outside of Tika) extract text from the PDF? If so what are the settings used from the command line?
    2. If Tesseract doesn't extract text outside of Tika then Tika won't b/c it's just a pass through to Tesseract on that part.

Tesseract is working from within Tika so no segregated jobs. But what if tika does some text extraction and does not pass the file to tesseract as well?
Thank you

hi @r00t1ng if you are calling Tesseract and it's working fine from within Tika, basically the best recommendation I have is to file some new JIRA tickets here http://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TIKA - attach the files (PDFs) that you are not having good results with and then identify what the expected text is.

Was looking to include this into the code base but the test image requires the default ImageMagick security limits (on Ubuntu at least) to be lifted. @pmweiss - do you have a smaller test image that would meet the limits?
